property"}]]}]]}]]}]]}],["$","section",null,{"className":"max-w-7xl mx-auto px-4 sm:px-6 lg:px-8 py-8 sm:py-12","children":["$","$L3",null,{"scenario":{"id":"tenant-rights","title":"Landlord Entering Your Rental","icon":"üè†","category":"Housing","description":"What to know about your rights as a tenant in a rental property","rights":[{"title":"Right to Advance Notice Before Entry","description":"Landlords cannot enter your rental without notice except in emergencies (fire, gas leak, police warrant). Most states require 24-48 hours' written notice. Entry is typically allowed only for repairs, inspections, or showings. You can be present during entry and can refuse if notice wasn't given properly.","source":"Implied Covenant of Quiet Enjoyment and State Landlord-Tenant Law","stateVariations":[{"state":"UT","note":"24-hour notice required for entry; 48 hours for non-emergency repairs"},{"state":"CA","note":"24-hour notice required; strong tenant privacy protections enforced"},{"state":"TX","note":"No specific statutory notice requirement for routine entry; reasonableness standard applies"},{"state":"NY","note":"24-hour notice required; tenants have strong privacy rights, especially in NYC"},{"state":"FL","note":"12-hour notice for repairs; 24-hour notice for other purposes"}]},{"title":"Right to Habitable Living Conditions","description":"Your landlord must provide a safe, livable space with functioning heat, hot water, structural integrity, and no hazards like mold or pest infestations. If conditions are unfit to live in, you may have rights to repair-and-deduct, rent withholding, or lease termination. Document problems with photos and written notice.","source":"Implied Warranty of Habitability (common law and state statute)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Habitability standard is strictly enforced; landlords must maintain property in safe condition"},{"state":"NY","note":"Housing Maintenance Code requires landlords meet strict habitability standards"},{"state":"TX","note":"Property Code requires landlord to make repairs timely; repair-and-deduct available"}]},{"title":"Right to Security Deposit Return","description":"Landlords must return your security deposit within a specific timeframe, usually 21-30 days after you move out. Any deductions must be itemized and documented. If your landlord keeps part of your deposit illegally, you can sue for the full amount plus damages and attorney fees.","source":"State Landlord-Tenant Statutes and Deposit Protection Laws","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"21 days to return deposit with itemized deductions; landlord pays damages if non-compliant"},{"state":"NY","note":"30 days to return deposit; strict documentation rules; interest required in some cases"},{"state":"TX","note":"30 days to return deposit; deductions must be itemized; treble damages available for wrongful withholding"},{"state":"UT","note":"30 days to return deposit; landlord must provide itemized deductions"},{"state":"FL","note":"15 days to return deposit; deductions must be itemized; disputes are common"}]},{"title":"Protection from Retaliatory Eviction","description":"Your landlord cannot evict you in retaliation for reporting code violations, habitability issues, or asserting your legal rights. Retaliatory actions are illegal. If you report a problem and then receive an eviction notice soon after, it may be retaliation. Keep records of all complaints and notices.","source":"State Landlord-Tenant Anti-Retaliation Statutes","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"Strong anti-retaliation protections; presumed retaliation if eviction within 180 days of complaint"},{"state":"NY","note":"Anti-retaliation law protects tenants; presumed retaliation within 6 months of complaint"},{"state":"TX","note":"Anti-retaliation protections exist but are narrower than some states"}]},{"title":"Right to Fair Housing","description":"You cannot be denied housing because of your race, color, religion, sex, national origin, disability, or familial status. Landlords cannot charge different rent, require different deposits, or set different terms based on protected characteristics. Report violations to HUD or your state's housing agency.","source":"Fair Housing Act of 1968 (42 U.S.C. ¬ß 3601 et seq.)","stateVariations":[{"state":"CA","note":"FEHA includes sexual orientation, gender identity, and marital status as protected classes"},{"state":"NY","note":"NY Human Rights Law includes source of income and sexual orientation protections"}]}]},"availableStates":["CA","FL","NY","TX","UT"]}]}],"$L4"]}],null,"$L5"]}],"loading":null,"isPartial":false}
